articles.title: Coronavirus may enter the brain by building tiny tunnels from the nose
articles.description: How the virus behind covid-19 enters the brain was somewhat of a mystery, but new evidence hints it may build tiny tubes from nose cells to brain cells that it can shuttle through
articles.content:
By Alice Klein
The coronavirus may build tubes that enable it to travel from nose cells to the brain
Anna Pepe, Pasteur Institute

articles.title: Coronavirus in late pregnancy raises premature birth risk seven-fold
articles.description: Testing positive for the coronavirus in the last three months of pregnancy may double the risk of a premature birth, rising to a seven-fold increased risk if infected after 34 weeks
articles.content:
By Clare Wilson

articles.title: Enceladus’s oceans may be the right saltiness to sustain life
articles.description: The geometry of the icy shell around Saturn’s moon Enceladus suggests that the ocean beneath is a little less salty than Earth’s oceans and could potentially sustain life
articles.content:

articles.title: Ear anatomy shows warm-blooded animals evolved 233 million years ago
articles.description: Analysis of inner ear canals from hundreds of modern and fossil animals shows that warm-bloodedness appeared abruptly in the late Triassic
articles.content:
By Christa Lesté-Lasserre
Warm-bloodedness may have enabled the ancestors of mammals to expand to colder areas

articles.title: Spinning rotors made from DNA could power minuscule machines
articles.description: Building devices at the nanoscale is difficult because small molecules move about randomly, but now researchers have made a working rotor using DNA

articles.title: A fish that evolved to stand up on land went back to living in water
